content:
Odd is defined in Mathlib as follows:

/-- An element `a` of a semiring is odd if there exists `k` such `a = 2*k + 1`. -/
def Odd (a : α) : Prop := ∃ k, a = 2 * k + 1

QuestionL what does the alpha α do? I've looked up and down that source code but can't find an obvious answer.

I know it is supposed to ensue the parameter a is a smearing but I can't see how that connection happens here.

source: https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/blob/5d2ccbb3e5b5df402d3b88f4c9aa0cd2ac986130/Mathlib/Algebra/Ring/Parity.lean#L89-L89
α is the type of a, it represents the ambient semiring (e.g. Nat or Int)
It is defined here, and here another variable adds a [Semiring α] instance for this type

Two additional things are:

  • it's often useful to ask this question in an editor rather than statically, because then if you use your editor's "go to definition" functionality it will jump you to what \alpha's definition is (it's the line Mario linked of course)
  • if you don't know what a Semiring is (which no one would blame you for, I don't know what it is either in any real sense!) you might find it interesting to just confirm for yourself by retyping the Odd definition in a new file over some simpler thing, e.g. you can define it the same way as there but where alpha is a field if you know what those are, or else even just where it's the integers or the rationals. You should of course then see that it "compiles" just fine, and hopefully will have some of the properties you'll expect for oddness (just as the mathlib one does of course).
rzeta0 has marked this topic as resolved.

Mario Carneiro said:

α is the type of a, it represents the ambient semiring (e.g. Nat or Int)

thanks

does the second definition overwrite the first?
It adds to it -- it basically is saying "now give \alpha a semiring structure", so from then on anything you write can now assume one.
